customer_addr:
2976 E. State St Suite 120 #211
Eagle, ID 83616

citations.narrative:
On 12/1/2024 a parakeet was found flying outside the aviary enclosure in the adjacent guest playroom which houses an
open topped shark tank. Prior to catching the loose parakeet a staff member found it dead and floating in the shark tank.
Guests leaving the walk-in aviary are required to wait inside an exit room that is separated from the feeding room by a
closed door. The exit room is also roped off inside a secondary exit door until the attendant releases the guests, and no
birds were noted to have escaped after an encounter. Birds that are not protected from escape, hazards, or predation
may suffer from stress, injury, or death. Prior to the inspection exit briefing on 12/6/2024, a 5ft x 2ft full-length mirror was
placed in the secondary exit room to facilitate visualization of a bird that may try to escape sitting on a guest after an
encounter.
Housing facilities must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of birds housed in
them, employ measures that contain all birds securely, and protect the birds from injury.

One parakeet in the walk-in aviary was killed on 11/11/2024 when stepped on by a guest. Prior to this occurrence guests
were allowed to enter the atrium to feed a seed mixture to the birds from a ladle-like tool that has an attached bowl on the
end. During feeding, some seed falls on the ground. The birds land on the ground to get the spilled seed which puts them
at risk of injury and death. Prior to the inspection on 12/6/2024 the facility switched to a larger pelleted feed which reduces
the potential for feed spilled on the floor and guests are now required to sit on benches during the interaction. After an
encounter but before guests stand up from the bench, an attendant claps and encourages the birds to fly back to their
roosting tree.
The facility must take measures to ensure safe handling with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the birds and the
general viewing public to assure the health and safety of all animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
On 12/1/2024 a parakeet was found flying outside the aviary enclosure in the adjacent guest playroom which houses an 
open topped shark tank. Prior to catching the loose parakeet a staff member found it dead and floating in the shark tank. 
Guests leaving the walk-in aviary are required to wait inside an exit room that is separated from the feeding room by a 
closed door. The exit room is also roped off inside a secondary exit door until the attendant releases the guests, and no 
birds were noted to have escaped after an encounter. Birds that are not protected from escape, hazards, or predation 
may suffer from stress, injury, or death. Prior to the inspection exit briefing on 12/6/2024, a 5ft x 2ft full-length mirror was 
placed in the secondary exit room to facilitate visualization of a bird that may try to escape sitting on a guest after an 
encounter.  
 
Housing facilities must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of birds housed in 
them, employ measures that contain all birds securely, and protect the birds from injury. 
2.131(c)(1)  Critical Repeat
   
Handling of animals. 
One parakeet in the walk-in aviary was killed on 11/11/2024 when stepped on by a guest. Prior to this occurrence guests 
were allowed to enter the atrium to feed a seed mixture to the birds from a ladle-like tool that has an attached bowl on the 
end. During feeding, some seed falls on the ground. The birds land on the ground to get the spilled seed which puts them 
at risk of injury and death. Prior to the inspection on 12/6/2024 the facility switched to a larger pelleted feed which reduces 
the potential for feed spilled on the floor and guests are now required to sit on benches during the interaction. After an 
encounter but before guests stand up from the bench, an attendant claps and encourages the birds to fly back to their 
roosting tree. 
 
The facility must take measures to ensure safe handling with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the birds and the 
general viewing public to assure the health and safety of all animals. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
